div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1880.
Editor & Manager .... R. Snelling.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1905.

div.head:
DISSOLUTION IMMINENT.
MEETING OF CABINET.
LIBERAL PROGRAMME.

div.p: Neither party generally nor Mr. Chamberlain has responded to Mr. Balfour's appeal. The "Times" foreshadows an immediate dissolution.

Considerable interest has been caused in political circles by strong hints, both in the "Times" and "Daily Telegraph," that Mr. Balfour should, in view of Mr. Chamberlain's attitude, take an early opportunity for resigning. The Liberals would then form a Government, and Parliament would be dissol- ved alter a brief meeting.

A meeting of the Cabinet will be held to- morrow. Rumour anticipates that the result will be the first step towards resignation, which today is the absorbing topic. The Liberal newspapers declare that Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman will refuse to form a Cabinet under the present circumstances, and will insist on dissolution. (Reuter)

The Sultan has sent Admiral Husni to the Dardanelles. It is stated that he bears instruc- tions to the commander of the forts in view of the contingency of an international blockade. Instruction have also been sent to the gover- nors of Mityleno and other islands. (Reuter)
The ships of the Powers that are to take part in the naval demonstration against Tur- key have arrived at tho Pireus. (Havas)

div.head:
NEW JAPANESE LOAN.
DIVISION AMONG CAPITALS.

div.p: Twenty-five millions of the Japanese Loan have been issued at ninety. Paris takes twelve millions, London six and a half millions, New York three and a quarter, and Berlin three and a quarter millions. (Reuter)

The city is beflagged and thronged to-day in honor of the departure of King Hakon and Queen Maud for Christiania. Both were deeply moved by the farewell King Christian and the Royal family on the quay and the forts saluted as the royal yacht Dannebrog hoisted the royal flag of Norway and steamed out, escorted by the flotilla of warships, which Prince Henry of Prussia joined at Elsimore. (Reuter)
The circulation of trains throughout Russia has become normal again. (Havas)
M. Revoil will represent France at the Algesiras Conference. (Havas)

div.head: Tourists.
div.p: The British steam yacht Argonant arrived at Alexandria to-day from Port Said.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The Brindisi mail will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The Legislative Council will meet on December 2, to study the Budget for 1906.

div.head: Wakfs Administration.
div.p: Maitre Saint-Plancat has been appointed counsel to the Wakfs Administration.

div.head: Gambling Hall Raid.
div.p: The Cairo police raided a gambling hell in the Wagh el-Birket quarter of Cairo on Wednesday night.

div.head: Fatal Accident.
div.p: A native boy of 3 years was run over and killed yesterday by a cart in the Labbane quarter. The driver was arrested.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: Fourteen vessels passed through the Canal on the 20th inst., of which 8 wore British, 3 German, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch, 1 Russian. The total receipts from the 1st to the 20th inst. were frs. 6,884,866.08.

div.head: Credit Lyonnais.
div.p: M. Adon, sub manager of the Credit Lyon- nais at Cairo, has been appointed to succeed M. Petcovich, as sub-manager of the Alexandria branch of the bank. M. Lascaris will succeed M. Adon at Cairo.

div.head: Fatira Company.
div.p: An application has been made to the Com- mittee of the London Stock Exchange to appoint a special settling day in—Fatira (Egypt) Exploring Company, Limited, 10,007 shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 7 and 65,008 to 75.007.

div.head: Union Fonciere.
div.p: Application his been made to the Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in and to grant a quotation to— L'Union Fonciere D'Egypte, share warrants to bearer for 100,000 shares of £5 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 100000.

div.head: Copts and the Railways.
div.p: "Al Lewa" publishes an article three col- umns in length urging the reconstituted Board of tho Railway Administration to employ Mos- lems and Copts according to the numerical proportion they respective'y bear to the popu- lation, i.e., 95 per cent. Moslems and 5 per cent Copts.

div.head: Tuberculosis in Egypt.
div.p: The league, which was founded at Alexandria some years ago to combat the ravages of tubercolusis in Egypt, has published its financial statement for the twelve months up to June 30. During the year P.T. 59,439 1 was collected, and after all expenses are deducted, there remains a balance of P.T. 14,637 on the year's working.

div.head: Cairo Season.
div.p: The Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be reopened on Monday, the 27th inst. The management had to open a few days earlier than was intended owing to there being a number of families already waiting in the different hotels fo move to the Savoy. They will there- fore have numerous guests right from the beginning. The Savoy is confident of a very good season.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Judicial Adviser came down to Alexandria yesterday evening.
The Marquis Salvago Raggi and Count Manzoni called upon the Ministers aud representatives of the Powers on Wednesday.
We are pleased to announce that the French Government has conferred on H.E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidki, Governor of Alexandria, the grade of Officer of the Legion of Honor.
Major C. R. Heastey, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted leave of absence, pending retirement, from December 5.

div.head: PENNY POSTAGE TO EGYPT.
A MISAPPREHENSION.
div.p: Some misunderstanding appears to have arisen as to tho recent petition in favor of placing Egypt on the same footing as the component parts of the British Empire in respect to penny postage. For example, a Cairo French contemporary commented on the petition in the following terms: -

La petition sinsi presentee no laisse pas d'etre gaie. Faut-il que les signataires aient onblie que les postes sont soumises a une convention internationale, et que s'il appar- tient au gouvernement égyptien de donner la preference aux anglais pour le service dans ses administrations, il ne peut favoriser l'Angle- terre d'nne taxe postale speciale.

Qu'on demande la reduction pour tous les pays, cela n'aurait rien que de louable, et tout le monde applaudirait au project. Mais il serait peu charitable d'insister davantage sur l'inco- herence de la démarche des pétitionnaires. D'ailleurs S. E. Saba pacha, cousulte a ce anjet, leur a fait entendre qu'il approuverait pleinement la reduction a un penny de la taxe postale, pour tous les pays.

These opinions are erroneous, for in virtue of the Washington Convention Egypt can agree to accept lower postal rates, but is prohibited from increasing these rates. Thus it would be quite feasible for Egypt to enter into conven- tion on this subject with the British Govern- ment.

div.head: POST CARD FACILITIES.
div.p: The Egyptian postal authorities have been informed that the English Post Office bas decided in principle to accept the receipt of postcards from all other countries with half of the address side allotted for correspondence. No date has, however, yet been given as to when this new regulation will come into force.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY, LTD.
div.p: The report of the New Egyptian Company, Limited, has just been issued. A profit of £45,000 has been realised and a dividend of 2s.6d. per share or 12.5%, has been declared. The assets of the company, excluding lands reclaimed in the bed of the Nile, by virtue of its concassion from the Egyptian Government, show an appreciation of £100,000.

div.head: BANK OF ROME.
div.p: The question of establishing a branch of the Bank of Rome at Cairo is under discussion. M. Pacelli, chairman of the board of directors, and M. Benucci, managing director of the bank, are proceeding to Cairo for this purpose.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: H H. the Khedive has conferred a number of decorations and grades on the officials of the Daira Sinieh Administration on the occasion of its final liquidation. Ahmed Balig Pasha, Director General, has received the Grand Cordon (1st class) of the Order of the Medjidieh, and Birch Pasha, Inspector General, the grade of Grand Officer (2nd class) of the same Order. The grade of Commander (3rd class) of the Order of the Osmanieh has been conferred on Fonrneron Bey, chief engineer, and M. Gaston Privat, advocate. Ahmed Rifaat Pasha, Sub- Inspector-General, has been raised to the rank of Mirmiran.
His Highness has also conferred the grade of Officer (4th class) of the Order of the Med- jidieh on Mr. C. T. Currelly, of the Egypt Exploration Fund.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The cashier of the Anglo-Egyptian Spinning and Weaving Company was committed for trial yesterday at the British Consular Court, Alexandria. He will be tried for embezzlement at the forthcoming session of the Supreme Con- sular Court.

div.head: AMERICAN CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The trial of M. Vonreky, an American citizen of Hellenic extraction, who follows the calling of a broker at Alexandria, took place yesterday afternoon at the American Con- sular Agency before the Hon. Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul- General. The accused was charged with assaulting a Greek coffee-house keeper of Alexandra by throwing him out of his office. The case was eventually settled by a compre- mise, the plaintiff agreeing to accept P.T. 100 from the defendant.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah arrived at Li- verpool yesterday afternoon.
The Moss liner Seti sailed this morning for Manchester via Malts, with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 7,030 bales cotton.
The Conard S.S. Brescia sailed direct for Liverpool yesterday afternoon with a fall cargo including 6,672 bales cotton.
The S.S. Spartan Prince, from Manchester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterday, and is due at Alexandria on Monday.

div.head: CAIRO DOG REGULATLONS.
HINTS TO OWNERS
div.p: On the 1st proximo the decree concerning the measures to be adopted in Cairo in the case of rabies will come into force.

Kennels for 50 dogs have now been established at the infirmary of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Boulac. All stray dogs of every description will be arrested by the police and taken to these kennels.
There is no registration for dogs, nor do the authorities supply medals (metal plaques) for same, but proprietors should see that they wear a collar or medal, bearing their name and address.
A dog found by the police will be kept a period of seven days pending claim. After the seventh day, it will be disposed of if unclaimed.

In the event of a dog being lost; the pro- prietor can visit the kennels, and should the dog be there, application should be made to the Traffic Office, Gonvernorat, for same to be handed over after payment for keep.

ShouId a case of rabies or suspected rabies occur in any locality, an arrete will at once be published, allowing three days from date of publication for all dogs to be muzzled or led on leash, or both. Owners of dogs are there- fore, advised to procure muzzles and leashes in case of accident.

div.head: AUTOMOBILE CLUB.
div.p: At the meeting held last night of automobile owners at the Mohamed Aly Club, it was decided to form an Automobile Club, which is to be amalgamated with the Automobile Club d'Egypte. The following committee was elected:—H.H. Prince Aziz (president), M. George Zervadachi, Baron Alfred de Meuasce, M. Constantin Choremi, M. M. C. Salvago, M. H. Fenderl, and Mr. A. C. Grafton (hon. secretary).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
SEVERO TORELLI.
div.p: Severo Torelli is one of those dramas in which declamation and humanity alike are extended to their limit. Fine and impassioned in its phrasing, and yet at the due moment condescending to exactly expressed familiarity, it should be a sure test, and crucial, for actors. The play presents tyrants, crime, oaths, to break which is to break the chains of Heaven, all, in a word, that we know of 15th-century Italy. As we have intimated, the verse has not that marble, and statuesque rigidity which needs unduly phenomenal acting to transform it from literature to life. We saw it on Wednesday night played by a caste who are versed in all the essentials of the highest French drama. A criticism is somewhat difficult. One has to admit that attention was concentrated wholly on the four chief "stars." The others never seemed to break away from the school and tradition and rhythm. Mile Jeanne Delvair and M. Lambert pere were undoubtedly the best for interpretation and nataral effective "human" acting, but yet we cannot be sure that M. Lambert fils did not reach the highest point of all, though he allowed himself at moments to be carried away by conventional and exaggerated trenzy, and indulged in the vocal crescendos and the looks of horror which must mar the illusion he so nearly maintained. But for the rest he had intonations, sadden changes of manner, gestures that were reality itself, car trying all the conviction that is in that really great drama; and we must admit again, that the other parts could not give occasion for such variety and scope. Donna Pia is a woman, and through Mile Delvair, a heroic woman, keeping, then announcing, and at last greatly avenging her twenty years' secret; but we need not discuss it—all women are potentially what we call "actresses," men have a harder task, as their emotions are usually more, separate from their life. For the rest, it was all of interest, well-staged, and with no inconsistencies or faults, the play is certainly a play to read and to see as it was given us on Wednesday. And what greater respect can we show to its interpreters than by criticizing so far as we may, from a psychological point of view, instead of giving the usual list of names with a sentence or two tasked on to each.
We cannot but recommend all who care for French drama to profit by the remaining performances of this company in Cario.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: OWNERS are reminded that nominations for the big races of 190 must reach the Hon. Secretary on before, the 1st December, 1903.

For the convenience of owners a special measuring day has been fixed for Wednesday the 29th November, 1905, when horses or ponies intended to be nominated in the big races for 1906 can be clawed, measured, aged, etc.

If this description of thetr critidrm of the coritrollers eetms too strorgly werdéd; let ns say thst in the opinion of ihe experts theéon- trollera' proposais were impnotioahle. Hère are some of their eritioisBir:—

" Peut-être, Mit. ha Contrôleurs ont on ponr d'on éobe# qqi.aurait dérangé-leor ooœbi- nrisrn d'exploitation provisoire, oar.ils n'ignm rent pas que là Société éotueJls* °°°' fiance do pays et que l'assnrence * k eanna en quantité snffi'ante daoaj.'àvemr uniquement de œtf confia « qai dort Ihe

gros propriétaires étant intéressés pourraient apporter l'appui de leurs productions en cannes. Dans ces conditions les groupes isolés auraient moins de charges sociales à rémunérer, un fonds de roulement limité, des frais d'adminis tration très réduits et pourraient ainsi obteni un résultat industriel réel et suffisant.

"Dans ces conditions, lea Voies Ex-Daïra seraient divisées en zones comme d'ailleurs la New-Daïra l'avait prévu lorsqu'elle avait en- visagé la vente partielle des Usines, en laissant un passage libre sur une des lignes principales pour le besoin de toutes les sucreries.

"Messieurs les Contrôleurs paraissent ac- capter avec une réelle insouciance la vente dès réreaux des voies agricoles Ex Daira, plus pré- occupés en leur qualité de financiers de rés- liser des fonds que d'assurer l'avenir de l'ex- ploitation qu'ils se proposent de reconstituer. Nous estimons que cette aliénation quelles que soient les réserves faites et les garanties doa- nées par l'acquéreur qui, dans l'espèce ne serait autre que le Gonvernement, serait préjudiciable ADX. Usines desservies et à la Société. Les rai- sons en sont nombreuses et la pratique dé montrerait vite que l'approvisionnement ré gulier, déjà si difficile dans les conditions actuelles, deviendrait impossible dans l'avenir.

"Dans tous les cas, ce n'est pas à une administration agonisante, encore moins à une administration provisoire et incertaine, d'a- liéner une des parties les plus essentielles de Bon exploitation et dont elle n'a pas su et ne peut pas savoir tout le parti que l'on peut tirer.

"Cette vente n'est pas indispensable pour trouver les 350 à 400 mille Livres Sterling qu'elle pourrait donner; nous estimons qu'il serait plus rationnel de vendre immédiatement les Usines arrêtées de Dabayeh, Minieh et Magagah; les bateaux de plaisance; l'im- meable du Siège Social dont on pourrait retirer en ce moment, à cause de la hausse des terrains, L.E. 25,000 à 30,000; tout le maté riel des magasins et des parcs en ne conservant que le strict nécessaire pour une période de cinq années et, s'il le tallait, l'Usine de Bibeh avec son réseau de voies jusqu'à Magagah.

"Nous notons que les Contrôleurs considè- rent toute la dette de la Sagar Corporation comme privilégiée. Pour nous, nous considé- rons comme privilégiées les £944.000, valeur d'achat des Usines et Voies Ex-Daira.
"Mais quant aux £315.000 prêtées pour fonds de roulement c'est aux tribunaux de décider si cette somme est privilégiée au même titre que les £ 944.000.

"MM. les Contrôleurs se préoccupent sur- tout d'assurer le paiement de la charge fixe obligatoire qui serait de LE. 40.000 pendant les cinq premières années et de £ 43.840 lors- que l'amortissement commencera, prévoient que les diverses économies à réaliser seraient suffisantes: mais il y a aussi les porteurs. d'actions privilégiées et les porteurs d'actions ordinaires qui ont également le droit de toucher des intérêts ou des dividendes comme on lear fait espérer : il faudrait donc que les bénéfices fassent tels qu'ils puissent assurer le paiement des charges sociales suivantes : Charges obligatoires
5% aux Actions privilégiées 5% aux Actions ordinaires
Total

"MM. les Contrôleurs auraient pu ajouter à leurs propositions une étude montrant com. ment et au moyen de quelles économies l'affaire, remise sur pied, pourrait permettre de rétribuer toutes ces charges sociales, solder les frais d'administration qui ne sauraient être négligés, amortir les usines, et aussi payer les transfor- mations nouvelles à faire ou à compléter.

Nous estimons que l'industrie améliorée, à condition d'avoir la canne nécessaire et dans de meilleures conditions, pourrait donner des résultats meilleurs que par le passé, mais jamais de bénéfices suffisants pour supporter de pareilles charges, et nous craignons qu'après les deux années d'essai proposées une liquida tion ne s'impose, liquidation qui serait plus désastreuse qu'aujourd'hui, car les créanciers actuele qui auraient déjà consenti à une ré- daction de 20 0/0 sur leurs créances se trou versient alors exposés à voir le passif ang menté, l'actif diminué et une créance privi légiée absorber la meilleure et la plus grande partie de cet actif.

"Quant au bilan que MM. les Contrôleurs ont annexé à leur rapport il nous semble que le système employé par eax de porter à l'actif les Usines pour leur prix d'achat ou celui ré- sultant des écritures sans en faire une estima tion nouvelle plus approximative n'est pas exact. De ce fait, résulte pour la grande part, la différence existant entre le déficit présenté par leur bilan soit Livres 1.377 306 et celui de notre, £ 2.682.550, soit le double à peu prè "Nos critiques montrent assez clairement que les propositions de MM. les Contrôleur n'ont pas été étudiées avec précision et que lear essai de deux années ne saurait êt concluant.

"A notre avis le manque d'avenir de cette Société réside dans le fait qu'elle n'a pas acheté les terrains que la New Daira Sanieh avait réservé pour les usines et qu'elle l'engageait fortement à prendre."

The reading over, Me. Carton de Wiart ra marked that the experts, who were the manda- tories of the law like the controllers, had criticised the latter in their absence with considerable violence, Judge Tuck disagreed; the experts were mandatories, the controllers were not, in his opinion. Another discos ion followed and Judge Tack again proved inex orable. At 4.30 all was over; Me. Carton de Wiart stated that the final proposals would be submitted to the shareholders on Saturday next (to-morrow), and it was finally decided that the creditors' final meeting should come off at 3 p.m. on Friday, December 1.
Notre Revue Commerciale hebdomadaire paraitra à partir de ce jour régulièrement le Samedi Midi L'abonnement spécial à cette revue ne coûte gue P.T. 50 par an,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Adjurd'hui à midi et demis) Par suite de rashats la cote reprend sur toute la ligne,

La National Bank hausse de 25 8/32 à 25 1/2, l'Agricole de 9 1/16 à 9 1/4, la Banque d'Abyssinie de 7 à 7 3/16, la Béhéra de 37 à! 38, la Building Lands de 4 1/16 à 4 1/8, le Comptoir de 4 3/16 8 4 1/4, l'Investment de 1 1/16 à 1 3/32, la Delta Land de 2 1/16 à 2 1/4, les Estates de 1 1/4 à 1 9/32, la New Egyptian de 29 à 31, l'Union Foncière de 5 7/8 à 5 15/16, la Salt & Soda de 23 & 23/9 l'Anglo-American Nile de 5 7/16 à 5 1/2, la Khedivial Mail de 4 1/4 à 4 5/16 et la Ramleh Railway de 6 9/16 à 7.

La tendance est momentanément pour la ha 18se mais on craint que ce bon mouvement ne dure guère, étant du en partie à des rachats da découvert et en partie à l'amélioration de nouvelles politiques toujours sujettes à des revirements.

div.head: The Egpytian Salt and Soda Co.
div.p: SUPPLY OP 600,000 SACKS FOR THE
DISTRIBUTION OF SALT.
FIRMS desirous of tendering for these will please send their offers addressed to the Managing Director, Egyptian Salt & Soda Co, Ltd., Alexandria, endorsed "Salt Bags," on or before the 30th inat.

The bags must be of Jate woven 10 8 threads per inch, weighing at least 2 lbe. each. 30" wide by 42" long, of the type kaown as "Sagar" bags. A blue band 1" wide at a distance of 5" from each edge must be woven in the fabrio. No other remarks required. Delivery 50,000 per month commencing first week January 1906. i Samples may be seen at the Alexandria
Office "ex Huileries." i The Director does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any tendor.

div.head: BANQUE D'ATHENES
div.p: Societe Anonyme, Capital Dr. 20.000,000 entierement verze
M
Reserve Dr. 1.000.000
Athènes, le 7/20 Novembre 1905.

Nous avons l'honneur de vous informer que nous venons de créer au Caire rae-el-Maghrabi (immeuble Alti) une Agence de notre Etablisse- ment qai re'è vera directement de notre Succar- sale d'Alexandrie.
Monsieur Pan. G. Schisas, Sous-Directeur à Alexandrie a été nommé Directeur de cette Agence et signers conjointement avec Mon- sieur Jean G. Souliotis, Caissier.

Nous vous prions de noter que Monsieur Jean Joannidès, notre Directeur à Alexandrie, assume la direction supérieure de nos Agences d'Egypte et aura, en cette qualité, le droit de signature an Caire dans les mêmes conditions qu'à Alexandrie.
Veuillez prendre note de la signature de Monsieur Jean G. Souliotis, les autres yous étant déjà connues et agréer, Messieurs, l'as- surance de notre considération distinguée.
BANQUE D'ATHENES
Le Président du Conseil d'Administration et Directeur Général
JEAN G. PESMAZOGLOU.

div.head: Direction Generale des Douanes
div.p: AVIS

La Direction Générale des Douanes a l'hon- neur de porter à la connaisance du public. qu'à l'occasion des fêtes du Bairam, ses bureaux ainsi que ceux des Donanes d'Alex- andrie, de Mahmoudieh, des Tabacs et de toutes les autres Branches Donanières, seront fermés les mardi et mercredi, 28 et 29 Novembre 1905.

Les portes et magasins des Douanes d'Alex- andrie et de Mahmoudieh seront ouverts le dimanche 26 courant sans "Nobatgieh" pour le retrait on chargement de marchandises sur lesquelles les formalités auraient déjà été accomplies.
Alexsadrie, le 26 Ramadan 1323 (28 Novembre 1905.) 2677-1

div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
